title: Gigi Perreau
text:
Gigi Perreau (born February 6, 1941) is an American film and television actress.
Early years.
The daughter of <a href="France">French</a>-born Robert and Eleanor Child Perreau-Saussine, she was born Ghislaine Elizabeth Marie Thérèse Perreau-Saussine.
Career.
Perreau achieved success as a <a href="child%20actor">child actress</a> in a number of films. She got into the business quite by accident. Her older brother <a href="Peter%20Miles%20%28American%20actor%29">Gerald</a> was trying out for the part of the title character's son in "<a href="Madame%20Curie%20%28film%29">Madame Curie</a>" (1943). Because their mother could not find a babysitter, she took Gigi along. The two-year-old, who could speak French, got the (uncredited) part of Madame Curie's daughter <a href="%C3%88ve%20Curie">Ève</a> (while Gerald would have to wait a year to make his film debut in "<a href="Passage%20to%20Marseille">Passage to Marseille</a>").
She also played the daughter of <a href="Claude%20Rains">Claude Rains</a> and <a href="Bette%20Davis">Bette Davis</a>'s characters in the 1944 film "<a href="Mr.%20Skeffington">Mr. Skeffington</a>" (1944). In "<a href="Shadow%20on%20the%20Wall%20%28film%29">Shadow on the Wall</a>" (1950), she starred as the sole witness to a murder. As the "top child movie actress for 1951", the then ten-year-old was given the keys to the city of <a href="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a> by its mayor, and later <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> governor, <a href="David%20L.%20Lawrence">David L. Lawrence</a>. She was the youngest person to be so honored. Perreau played the rebellious teen daughter of <a href="Fredric%20March">Fredric March</a> in 1956's "<a href="The%20Man%20in%20the%20Gray%20Flannel%20Suit">The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit</a>". However, her film career lost momentum as she became an adult, so she turned to television.
In 1959, she played a friend of character Mary Stone (<a href="Shelley%20Fabares">Shelley Fabares</a>) on <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>'s "<a href="The%20Donna%20Reed%20Show">The Donna Reed Show</a>", and had a supporting role in the <a href="sitcom">sitcom</a> "<a href="The%20Betty%20Hutton%20Show">The Betty Hutton Show</a>" on <a href="CBS">CBS</a>, with her brother Gerald. In 1960, Perreau and <a href="Robert%20Harland">Robert Harland</a> performed as Sara Lou and Lin Proctor, a young couple from the east who have <a href="elopement">eloped</a> and are heading west, in the ABC western series "<a href="Stagecoach%20West%20%28TV%20series%29">Stagecoach West</a>" episode "The Land Beyond", with <a href="Wayne%20Rogers">Wayne Rogers</a> and <a href="Robert%20Bray">Robert Bray</a>. Also in 1960, Perreau was cast as Julie Staunton in the episode "Flight from Terror" of the ABC adventure series "<a href="The%20Islanders%20%28TV%20series%29">The Islanders</a>", set in the <a href="Oceania">South Pacific</a>. She was cast in two episodes, "Don Gringo" (1960) and "The Promise" (1961), of the <a href="Nick%20Adams%20%28actor%2C%20born%201931%29">Nick Adams</a> ABC <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> series "<a href="The%20Rebel%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">The Rebel</a>". In 1961, she played Mary Bettelheim in the episode "The Twelfth Hour" of the ABC/<a href="Warner%20Brothers">Warner Brothers</a> television <a href="crime%20drama">crime drama</a> "<a href="The%20Roaring%2020s%20%28TV%20series%29">The Roaring 20s</a>". She was cast in a recurring role on ABC's "<a href="Follow%20the%20Sun%20%28TV%20series%29">Follow the Sun</a>" series from 1961–1962 as a secretary, Katherine Ann "Kathy" Richards. She guest-starred on "<a href="The%20Rifleman">The Rifleman</a>" in 1960 and 1961. She made two guest appearances on "<a href="Perry%20Mason%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Perry Mason</a>": in 1958 as title character and defendant Doris Bannister in "The Case of the Desperate Daughter" and in 1964 as nurse Phyllis Clover in "The Case of the Sleepy Slayer." In 1964, she also co-starred as Lucy, a beleaguered homesteader, on an episode of "<a href="Gunsmoke">Gunsmoke</a>" titled "Chicken". In 1970, she appeared on the <a href="sitcom">sitcom</a> "<a href="The%20Brady%20Bunch">The Brady Bunch</a>" in the episode "The Undergraduate", portraying a math teacher who becomes the object of <a href="puppy%20love">puppy love</a> by Greg Brady, one of her students.
In the 2000s, she provided her voice in the animated films "<a href="Fly%20Me%20to%20the%20Moon%20%28film%29">Fly Me to the Moon</a>" (2008), "" (2010) and "Crash: The Animated Movie" (2017), and acted in "Time Again" (2011).
Affiliations.
Perreau is an alumna of <a href="Immaculate%20Heart%20High%20School%20%28Los%20Angeles%29">Immaculate Heart High School</a> in Los Angeles and has taught drama classes there. As of 2010, she was a member of the board of directors of both the <a href="Donna%20Reed">Donna Reed Foundation for the Performing Arts</a> and the <a href="Theatricum%20Botanicum">Will Geer Theatricum Botanicum</a> and is the vice-president of the Drama Teachers Association of Southern California.
She was a drama teacher for <a href="Meghan%20Markle">Meghan Markle</a>. She was a guest of <a href="ITN">ITN</a> at Markle's wedding in 2018 and was recognised by her in the crowd.
Honors.
On February 8, 1960, Perreau was awarded a star on the <a href="Hollywood%20Walk%20of%20Fame">Hollywood Walk of Fame</a> for her work in television.
On March 14, 1998, she was honored by the <a href="Young%20Artist%20Award">Young Artist Foundation</a> with its <a href="Young%20Artist%20Former%20Child%20Star%20Lifetime%20Achievement%20Award">Former Child Star "Lifetime Achievement" Award</a> in recognition of her outstanding achievements within the entertainment industry as a <a href="child%20actor">child actress</a>.
Personal life.
Perreau's elder brother Gerald (stage name <a href="Peter%20Miles%20%28American%20actor%29">Peter Miles</a>) and, to a lesser extent, her younger sisters Janine and Lauren, also had a measure of success in film and on television. Gigi and Janine portrayed sisters on screen in "<a href="Week-End%20with%20Father">Week-End with Father</a>" (1951).
Perreau, 19, married 35-year-old Emil Frank Gallo, a business executive in 1960; it was the first marriage for both parties. They had two children: Gina Maria Gallo Paris, a filmmaker, and <a href="Anthony%20Gallo">Robert Anthony Gallo</a>, a guitarist. They divorced in 1967.
She wed Gene Harve deRuelle in 1970, a production manager and son of director Harve Foster, with whom she had two additional children: Danielle deRuelle Bianco and Keith deRuelle. Her second marriage ended in 2000.
